entry.headline: Tellme speaks in a new language for Microsoft
entry.body:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Mike McCue never imagined he would be an employee of Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) -- the company that crushed his former employer, Netscape, during the Web browser wars of the late 1990s.

As chief executive and co-founder of Tellme Networks Inc, an early leader in search on mobile phones that was acquired by the software giant in March, McCue now stands at the forefront of Microsoft's strategy in two areas: online services and voice-recognition technology.

Tellme brings to Microsoft the world's largest database of voice-recognition data, and employees versed in a Web-based business model that threatens Microsoft's traditional, out-of-the-box software business.

"Microsoft is trying to advance in areas that it hasn't been familiar with in the past. It is trying to embrace the differences, not eliminate them," McCue said in an interview with Reuters on the sideline of the Web 2.0 Expo.

"We don't sell any software. It's only services."

Tellme will stay in its offices in the heart of Silicon Valley, hundreds of miles away from Microsoft's Redmond, Washington campus, and operate like an independent entity within the $44 billion software maker

"When you empower a team and tell them do whatever you need to do and make whatever technology decisions, they can operate like a start-up inside the company," said McCue. "Ten years ago, that would have never happened."

Microsoft did not disclose how much it paid for Tellme, but sources familiar with the situation previously told Reuters the companies were in talks for a deal that could value the company at more than $800 million. At that price, it would be Microsoft's biggest acquisition since 2002.

Tellme launched a new mobile search service on Tuesday, which allows users to request information by voice free of charge and see the results pop up with maps and directions on the phone's screen.

The Tellme acquisition is expected to enhance Microsoft's position in searches done from mobile phones, which the company sees as a relatively untapped market where it can compete more favorably with current Web search leader Google Inc. (GOOG.O) and with Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O)

At the heart of Tellme's service is a voice-recognition database that allows the company to accurately predict what information callers are seeking and decipher many different accents and dialects. Tellme said it adds 9 billion "utterances" a year to its database.

"It's one of the assets that Microsoft valued pretty highly," said McCue. "Mobile search and PC search will be very different things. The leaders in PC search won't necessarily be the leaders in mobile search."

McCue also brings to Microsoft extensive experience in operating a software-as-a-service business.

Microsoft built its business selling software that runs on a computer's hard drive and it is moving to adopt elements of the online services movement to deliver software as a service through the Web browser.

It's a business model long embraced by Google and other Internet companies, but somewhat new territory to Microsoft.

In order to facilitate that strategic shift, Microsoft is investing billions in new massive data centers filled with computers servers, storage equipment and network systems.

"Microsoft is the underdog right now with tens of billions (in cash) behind them," said McCue. "Microsoft has the will, the courage, the intent to make software as a service happen."

McCue said he remembers another time when Microsoft was the underdog. He was the vice president of technology at Netscape, which at the time was the dominant Web browser with a healthy lead over Microsoft's Internet Explorer.

"Microsoft came and beat us pretty good," McCue said with a laugh. "I learned a huge lesson there."

entry.author: Philipp Gollner
entry.headline: IBM profit up on software and services
entry.body:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - International Business Machines Corp. (IBM.N), the world's largest technology services company, said on Tuesday that quarterly profit rose 8 percent on higher sales of software and computer services.

Net income rose to $1.84 billion, or $1.21 per share, matching Wall Street estimates. A year earlier, it earned $1.71 billion, or $1.08 per share.

Revenue climbed 6.6 percent to $22.03 billion from $20.66 billion a year earlier and topped expectations of $21.9 billion, according to Reuters Estimates.

Following the earnings report in after-hours trading, IBM shares slipped 91 cents to $96.21 after closing up 1 percent.

"The worry going into the quarter was sluggishness (in) server spending, but the fact that IBM pulled off the quarter shows that the diversified portfolio of businesses is working," said Sunil Reddy, senior portfolio manager at Fifth Third Asset Management, which oversees about $21 billion, including IBM shares.

The company stood by its January forecast of full-year earnings-per-share growth of 10 percent to 12 percent, adding that growth would likely be around 11 percent.

IBM Chief Financial Officer Mark Loughridge told analysts on a conference call that weakness in the United States was more than offset by strong sales in Asia and in Europe, especially in Germany.

IBM paid nearly $5 billion for 13 acquisitions to boost sales of software and services last year, part of a strategy to improve profitability by selling more software-based services.

IBM said revenue at its two services businesses, which accounted for more than one-half of total sales in 2006, rose 8 percent in the quarter. Services signings, a key indicator of future revenue, slipped to $11.1 billion from $11.4 billion.

Revenue at one services unit, Global Business Services, increased 8.7 percent to $4.2 billion. It was the eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year pretax profit growth for the business, reflecting IBM's push to sell more-profitable software-based services.

Revenue at the other services unit, Global Technology Services, rose 7 percent to $8.3 billion. The first unit includes consulting and managing of customers' business software, while the other is involved in outsourcing and computer maintenance.

First-quarter services deals included a $775 million contract to manage information technology for more than 600 Circuit City CC.N stores.

IBM, of Armonk, New York, also signed a $700 million extension of a contract with Germany's Sparkassen Informatik GmbH, which handles information technology for savings banks.

Software revenue rose 8.8 percent to $4.25 billion in the first quarter, helped by strong sales of IBM's middleware software for running corporate data networks. Middleware is a layer of software that connects applications or components.

Sales of hardware, including microprocessors and servers and storage gear for businesses, rose 2.3 percent to $4.52 billion.

The stock closed up 94 cents at $97.12 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Shares are down 2.3 percent this year amid investor concern over revenue and profit growth for 2007. The stock trades at about 14 times estimated 2007 earnings per share, compared with an average multiple of about 15 for companies on the Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX, including competitor Hewlett-Packard Co. (HPQ.N)

entry.author: Sue Pleming
entry.headline: Rights group urges U.S. to cancel Cambodian visa
entry.body:
WASHINGTON (Reuters) - A leading human rights group on Tuesday urged Washington to cancel a U.S. visa granted to Cambodia's police chief to attend counter-terrorism talks because of questions about his past.

Hok Lundy, Cambodia's top police officer, is set to attend counter-terrorism talks with FBI officials on Thursday and State Department spokesman Sean McCormack said there had likely been a "healthy discussion" before the visa was granted.

Lundy had requested a U.S. visa in 2005 but was turned down because of "what was believed to be credible evidence of complicity in human trafficking," said former senior State Department official John Miller, who was ambassador at large to stop human trafficking until a few months ago.

"Maybe he has redeemed himself in some way ... my advice to the FBI and Justice Department is that one should be careful when one sups with the devil," he said in a telephone interview.

According to the Human Rights Watch group, Lundy also allegedly was part of a conspiracy to carry out a grenade attack on opposition leader Sam Rainsy in March 1997. The attack killed 16 people and injured more than 150.

Human Rights Watch said the decision to grant Lundy a visa should be reversed because he had been implicated in crimes.

"Hok Lundy's alleged involvement in political violence and organized crime in Cambodia means that the FBI should be investigating him, not hosting him," Brad Adams, Asia director at Human Rights Watch, said in a statement.

Lundy previously has rejected the allegations of human trafficking but Miller said the police chief allegedly played a role in freeing eight traffickers just hours after they were seized in a raid in Cambodia.

"That the biggest trafficking raid with arrests could be overturned within hours ... does not happen without the complicity of the national chief of police," Miller said.

McCormack said a "policy judgment" was taken to let Lundy come to the United States, an indication that Lundy's contribution to the FBI counter-terrorism meeting outweighed questions about other issues.

"I know that there are a lot of allegations and I'm not trying to discount those allegations," McCormack said. "In adjudicating the visa, there were no legal bars to his receiving a visa."

"Obviously there was an inter-agency discussion and the FBI wanted him for his interests in terrorism issues," said Miller.

The FBI declined comment on the issue and referred all questions to the State Department.

entry.headline: Dow ends short of record on profits; IBM off late
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - The Dow industrials ended just short of a record high on Tuesday, helped by better-than-expected profits at companies such as Johnson Johnson (JNJ.N) and data showing tamer inflation.

Shares of health-care company Johnson Johnson and Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N), which also beat Wall Street forecasts, led advances in the Dow and the SP 500.

The Labor Department said the core Consumer Price Index, excluding food and energy, rose at a muted pace last month.

"The core CPI number was a big sigh of relief," said Mark Bronzo, managing director at Nationwide Separate Accounts LLC in Irvington, New York. "For people arguing we're in a stagflation environment of slower growth and higher inflation, that number sort of eases those concerns. On top of that, we got some good earnings from blue-chip names."

The SP 500 index hit a 6 1/2-year high, while Nasdaq ended down slightly ahead of results expected this week from some key technology companies.

The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI rose 52.58 points, or 0.41 percent, to end at 12,773.04. The Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX advanced 3.01 points, or 0.20 percent, to finish at 1,471.48. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC, however, slipped 1.38 points, or 0.05 percent, to 2,516.95.

The Dow's lifetime intraday high of 12,795.93 was hit February 20, a week before the February 27 global sell-off hit equities. During Tuesday's regular trading, the Dow hit a session high at 12,790.02 -- briefly surpassing its record close of 12,786.64, also set on February 20.

YAHOO AND IBM DROP AFTER THE BELL

After the close, Internet media company Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O) reported a lower quarterly profit that missed Wall Street estimates. Yahoo's stock dropped 8.7 percent to $29.29 in electronic trading. For details, see ID:nN1794147

International Business Machines Corp. (IBM.N) and chip maker Intel Corp. (INTC.O) also reported results after the bell. Intel shares rose 0.4 percent to $21.07 after hours while IBM shares fell 0.9 percent to $96.25. Both are in the Dow.

WHEN 'ZERO' ADDS UP

Shares of Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, rose 2.6 percent to $51.57. It said results were helped by the continued rollout of Coke Zero.

Johnson Johnson's stock gained 2.4 percent to $64.55.

"Expectations for earnings were relatively low, and so far the numbers aren't bad," Bronzo said.

First-quarter profit growth for SP 500 companies is projected at 4.5 percent, according to Reuters Estimates.

HOUSING SURPRISE

Stronger-than-expected data on housing starts and building permits, released before the opening bell, eased concerns about the extent of a housing slowdown. ID:nN16326600

Another report showed U.S. industrial production unexpectedly fell in March. ID:nN17403020

Home builders' shares gained after the housing data, with

Toll Brothers Inc. (TOL.N) rising 2.1 percent to $28.79, while Beazer Homes (BZH.N) climbed 2.7 percent to $30.48.

EMC Corp. (EMC.N), the top maker of corporate data storage equipment, also reported results that beat the average analyst forecast. Its shares rose 3.1 percent to $15.22.

Volume was moderate on the NYSE, where about 1.58 billion shares changed hands, below last year's estimated daily average of 1.84 billion. On Nasdaq, about 1.97 billion shares traded, below last year's daily average of 2.02 billion.

Advancing stocks and declining issues were almost evenly matched on the NYSE, where 1,616 stocks rose and 1,696 shares fell.

On Nasdaq, decliners outnumbered advancers by a ratio of about 3 to 2.

entry.headline: Coca-Cola reports higher first-quarter profit
entry.body:
(Adds revenue, details)

NEW YORK, April 17 (Reuters) - Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N), the world's largest beverage company, on Tuesday reported higher quarterly profit that beat Wall Street estimates as strength in emerging markets overshadowed weakness in North America.

Net income for the first quarter ended March 30 rose 14 percent to $1.26 billion, or 54 cents per share, from $1.11 billion, or 47 cents per share, a year earlier.

Excluding items including a charge from an asset write-off in a Philippines bottler and gains on the sales of an equity interest in a Brazilian bottler, the company earned 56 cents per share.

Analysts on average were expecting 53 cents per share, according to Reuters Estimates.

Coca-Cola, like rival PepsiCo Inc. (PEP.N), has seen a slowdown in sales in mature markets such as North America as increasingly health-conscious consumers opt for bottled water or tea.

Coke's North American sales were flat last year, while sales in Eurasia grew in the double-digits.

Net operating revenue rose 17 percent to $6.10 billion as worldwide unit case volume, a key metric in the beverage industry, grew 6 percent, helped by strength in Latin America, China, Eastern Europe, and South Africa.

Case volume was down 3 percent in North America, up 7 percent in Latin America, and up 11 percent in Europe.

Coke shares have been trading in their highest range since July 2004 in recent weeks. Before Tuesday, the the stock traded at more than 19 times estimated 2007 earnings, making it the second-priciest stock in the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI on a price to earnings basis, though its multiple is only slightly higher than that of rival PepsiCo.

entry.headline: Coke Zero boosts Coca-Cola
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N) posted a better-than-expected quarterly profit on Tuesday, as the continued roll-out of Coke Zero helped boost sales in many countries.

Shares were up nearly 3 percent in afternoon trade, as the results proved to many investors that there is growth left in the soft drink business and that Coke is able to capture it.

The Atlanta-based company said net income for the first quarter ended March 30 rose 14 percent to $1.26 billion, or 54 cents per share, from $1.11 billion, or 47 cents per share, a year earlier.

Excluding items including a charge from an asset write-off in a Philippine bottler and gains on the sales of an equity interest in a Brazilian bottler, the company earned 56 cents per share.

Analysts on average were expecting 53 cents per share on that basis, according to Reuters Estimates.

The world's No. 1 beverage company saw strong gains in emerging markets such as Russia, China and Africa, as well as moderate gains in developed markets like Japan and the European Union, which offset an expected decline in North America.

Coke, like rival PepsiCo Inc. (PEP.N), has suffered amid an industry-wide slowdown in the North American market as health-conscious consumers move away from soft drinks in favor of bottled waters, teas and energy drinks. While Coke Chief Executive E. Neville Isdell acknowledged that weakness on Tuesday, he delivered an optimistic message.

"We continue to expect 2007 to be weak," said Isdell on a conference call with analysts. "But we do expect to begin seeing sequential improvement in the second half of the year as we execute against our key goals."

Under the leadership of Isdell, who was brought out of retirement in 2004 to help turn the company around, Coke has introduced new products, smoothed relationships with bottlers, and launched a marketing campaign with the tagline "the Coke side of life."

"We took away (from the earnings) the impression that the strategies Isdell has been working on appear to be paying off," said Eric Schoenstein, an analyst at Jensen Investment Management in Portland, Oregon, which owns over 1 million Coke shares among its $3 billion in assets.

"It just looks like they're able to execute a little better than they had been previously," Schoenstein said.

Stifel Nicolaus analyst Mark Swartzberg called Tuesday's results "the best evidence yet that a nearly 3-year turnaround is working and that the company's long-term targets are sound and being achieved."

Swartzberg raised his earnings estimates and price target on Coke shares and reiterated his "buy" rating.

BY THE NUMBERS

Net operating revenue rose 17 percent to $6.10 billion as worldwide unit case volume, a key beverage industry metric, grew 6 percent, helped by strength in Latin America, China, Eastern Europe, South Africa, Nigeria and Russia.

"Coke's growth has lagged over the past five years and is now coming back," said Marc Heilweil, president of Spectrum Advisory Services, which owns 132,522 Coke shares. He noted, however, that the company got a little boost this quarter as an earlier Easter holiday this year shifted some sales seen last year in the second quarter to the first.

Case volume fell 3 percent in North America, but revenue in the area, which made up about 28 percent of the company's total, rose 2 percent, as Coke raised prices and sold a greater number of more-expensive energy and sports drinks.

Volume rose 17 percent in Africa, 7 percent in Latin America, 11 percent in the European Union, and 5 percent in the Pacific region. The Eurasia region, which includes South Asia, the Middle East, Russia and the Balkans, saw its volume rise 16 percent.

The results were driven by noncarbonated beverages such as Dasani bottled water, Powerade sports drink and Minute Maid juices, though soft drinks, which fell industry-wide in the U.S. for the past two years, rose 5 percent in the latest quarter, helped by the launch of Coca-Cola Zero, a no-calorie cola which tastes more like "the Real Thing" than Diet Coke.

Coke shares have traded in their highest range since July 2004 in recent weeks. Before Tuesday, the stock traded at more than 19 times estimated 2007 earnings, making it the second-costliest stock in the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI on a price-to-earnings basis, though its multiple is only slightly higher than that of rival PepsiCo.

Coke shares were up $1.29, or 2.6 percent, to $51.56 on the New York Stock Exchange in late afternoon dealings.

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-Chevron says ops unaffected at L.A. refinery
entry.body:
(Recasts with company statement)

HOUSTON, April 17 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) said a nitric oxide release reported to state regulators on Tuesday was not due to an operational problem at its 260,000 barrel per day (bpd) Los Angeles-area refinery in El Segundo, California.

The refinery detected a slightly higher flow of nitric oxide through the refinery flare on Tuesday morning and reported it to the California Office of Emergency Services out of "an abundance of caution," said spokesman Rod Spackman.

About 200 lbs of nitric oxide, a common byproduct of refining which can form nitrogen dioxide when mixed with oxygen, was released on Tuesday morning, according to a notice filed with the California Office of Emergency Services.

"This was not an operational issue," Spackman said.

entry.headline: US STOCKS-Blue chips rise on Coca-Cola, J&J earnings
entry.body:
(Updates to early morning)

By Kristina Cooke

NEW YORK, April 17 (Reuters) - U.S. blue-chip stocks edged higher on Tuesday, helped by data showing tamer March core consumer prices and after solid profits at companies such as Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N)

Shares of Coca-Cola were up 1.7 percent, while those of health-care company Johnson Johnson (JNJ.N), which also posted stronger-than-expected earnings, were up 3 percent.

"The general news flow has been positive," said David Katz, chief investment officer at Matrix Asset Advisors.

The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 22.26 points, or 0.17 percent, at 12,742.72. The Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX was up 1.72 points, or 0.12 percent, at 1,470.19. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was down 1.94 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,516.39.

Stronger-than-expected housing starts data, released before the opening bell, eased concerns about the subprime mortgage market. For details, see [ID:nN16326600], but another report showed U.S. industrial production unexpectedly fell in March. [ID:nN17403020]

Analysts also said traders were cautious, due to the weakness of the dollar, which breached the $2 level against sterling, as data showed a surge in UK inflation.

"When the dollar seems to be in a faster-than-desired decline, people get worried," said Katz.

Shares of Coca-Cola, the world's largest beverage company, rose to $51, while Johnson Johnson's stock rose to $65.15.

The Labor Department said the consumer price index, excluding food and energy, rose at a muted pace last month.

Other earnings due on Tuesday include Intel Corp. (INTC.O) and International Business Machines Corp.(IBM.N), both Dow components and both due after the market's close. Intel was up 0.9 percent at $20.88 and IBM rose 0.7 percent to $96.92. (Additional reporting by Ellis Mnyandu)

entry.headline: US STOCKS-Futures slip before CPI, Coca-Cola up
entry.body:
(Adds Coca-Cola, updates prices, changes byline)

By Kristina Cooke

NEW YORK, April 17 (Reuters) - U.S. stock futures fell on Tuesday as caution before consumer price data tempered reports of stronger-than-expected earnings from companies, including Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N)

Shares of Coca-Cola, a Dow component, rose 1.5 percent before the bell after the world's largest beverage company reported a quarterly profit that beat Wall Street estimates. For details see [ID:nN17379123]

Other earnings due on Tuesday include Dow components Intel Corp. (INTC.O), Johnson Johnson (JNJ.N) and International Business Machines Corp.(IBM.N).

Besides earnings, investors await economic reports, especially March consumer price data.

A sharp drop in the dollar against sterling after data showed inflation in Britain above 3 percent could put investors on edge. A fall in the dollar can add to pressure on U.S. prices and increase imports.

Investors will also get reports on housing starts and industrial production. On Monday the Standard Poor's 500 index rose to a 6 1/2-year high on signs of strength in the economy and corporate profits.

"CPI is the big concern for the market, and we've seen indications that inflation is still there in the system," said Peter Dunay, investment strategist at Leeb Capital in New York.

"With SP making a new multiyear high yesterday, it's not surprising to see the futures adding a little bit of caution to head lower. A weaker dollar adds evidence that it would be very difficult for the Fed to cut rates."

He added that stronger-than-expected earnings would cushion the market.

SP 500 futures SPc1 were down 2.70 points, below fair value, a mathematical formula that evaluates pricing by taking into account interest rates, dividends and time to expiration on the contract.

Dow Jones industrial average futures DJc1 were down 11 points and Nasdaq 100 NDc1 futures were off 4.50 points.

The Labor Department's CPI is forecast to rise 0.6 percent in March after rising 0.4 percent in February, according to economists polled by Reuters.

The core CPI, which excludes food and energy prices, was expected to rise 0.2 percent in March, matching February's gain. The prices report and the March housing data are due at 8:30 a.m. (1230 GMT).

Last week minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy-setting meeting said more interest rates increases could be needed to tame price pressures.

Coca-Cola's shares rose 1.5 percent to $51 in electronic trade.

(Additional reporting by Ellis Mnyandu)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-RESEARCH ALERT-Goldman cuts view on US biofuels sector
entry.body:
(Adds details)

April 17 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs cut its view on the U.S. biofuels sector to "cautious" from "neutral" on concerns of contracting ethanol margins due to higher corn prices and weakening ethanol prices.

The brokerage also cut ethanol provider Aventine Renewable Energy Holdings Inc. AVR.N to "neutral" from "buy", on valuation.

Ethanol prices would have to fall if it had to expand beyond its traditional markets, the Midwest and the reformulated gasoline markets, Goldman Sachs analyst Arjun Murti said in a research note.

The ethanol sector is expensive, with shares of both Aventine and VeraSun Energy Corp. VSE.N up about 39 percent from their 52-week lows seen early in the year, he observed.

Murti said he recommended selling ethanol shares into the rebound in prices since the U.S. Agriculture Department's Prospective Plantings report.

The report, issued on March 30, indicated US farmers intend to plant the largest amount of land to corn in 63 years, potentially enough to produce a record 12.5 billion-bushel crop. (Reporting by Kuncheria Cholemkeril in Bangalore)

entry.headline: China blocks baidu.jp to stop porn surfing -reports
entry.body:
SHANGHAI, April 17 (Reuters) - Beijing has blocked the Japanese Web search site of Baidu.com Inc. (BIDU.O), often described as "China's Google", in an effort to stop Chinese users from accessing pornographic material, media reports said on Tuesday.

Attempts to access Japanese-language www.baidu.jp in Beijing and Shanghai on Tuesday proved unsuccessful, while online media reports carried on Chinese Web site Sina.com said the site had been blocked after it was widely used to download pornographic images.

A spokesman at Beijing-based Baidu declined to comment.

Baidu, China's top Web search firm, started up the Japanese portal -- its first regular service outside its home market -- in March.

The company competes with global search leader Google Inc. (GOOG.O), whose Web search services includes Chinese- and Japanese-language portals.

China is the world's second-largest Internet market after the United States, with about 137 million Web users.

entry.headline: JPMorgan earnings rise
entry.body:
NEW YORK (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase Co. (JPM.N) on Wednesday said first-quarter earnings rose 55 percent, beating forecasts, as gains in investment banking and private equity outweighed weak growth in retail banking.

The strong results at the bank, which also raised its dividend and authorized a new $10 billion stock buyback plan, follow better-than-expected earnings at larger rival Citigroup (C.N) earlier this week.

JPMorgan shares were up 2.6 percent in electronic trading after the results.

"The results are clearly driven by investment banking, but retail banking is challenged right now, and JPMorgan is no exception," said analyst Bill Fitzpatrick of Johnson Asset Management in Racine, Wisconsin.

Net income at the No. 3 U.S. bank rose to $4.8 billion, or $1.34 a share, from $3.1 billion, or 86 cents a share, a year earlier.

Excluding a one-time gain from the adoption of a new accounting rule, JPMorgan earned $1.23 a share, beating the analysts' average forecast of $1.02, according to Reuters Estimates.

"They've got some credit quality issues but it appears as though they've got a good handle on it," Fitzpatrick said. "I think these diversified financials can stomach it better than the pure-play regional banks."

JPMorgan also said it was raising its quarterly dividend by 12 percent to 38 cents a share and authorized a new $10 billion stock buyback program.

The bank bought back $4 billion in stock in the first quarter, using up most of the authorization from a prior repurchase plan from 2006, Chief Financial Officer Mike Cavanaugh told reporters on a conference call.

At Tuesday's close, JPMorgan shares were up 3.9 percent so far this year, compared with a 1.9 percent decline in the KBW Banks index .BKX.

JPMorgan has been focused on growth, changing course from its previous focus on cost savings from a series of previous acquisitions and mergers.

Executives have said they planned to invest $1 billion in investment banking in 2007 -- about one third more than in 2006 -- to expand in markets such as energy trading in Asia.

Investment banking, one of the company's strongest areas in the quarter, posted an 81 percent gain in profit to $1.54 billion, helped by strong revenue from fees.

Retail banking earnings fell 2 percent to $859 million as provisions for credit losses more than tripled to $292 million from a year earlier due to higher losses from subprime mortgages and home equity loans.

Cavanaugh downplayed the importance of subprime for JPMorgan, noting that it accounted for only $20 million in charge-offs.

"We have subprime very well under control and are comfortable there," he said.

Problems with subprime mortgages, which are targeted to less-creditworthy borrowers, have shaken many smaller lenders and even rattled larger banks like Washington Mutual Inc.

(WM.N)

Gains on private equity investments helped JPMorgan's corporate bank swing to a $631 million profit from a $366 million loss in the year-ago period.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Mexico's Televisa posts surprise 1st-qtr profit plunge
entry.body:
(Adds details)

MEXICO CITY, April 18 (Reuters) - Mexican broadcaster Televisa posted a surprise 46 percent plunge in first-quarter earnings on Wednesday because of a sharp jump in expenses, losses at affiliates and higher taxes.

Grupo Televisa (TV.N) (TLVACPO.MX) said it earned 734 million pesos ($66 million), compared with 1.348 billion pesos in the first quarter of 2006. Results came in way below analysts' estimate of 1.450 billion pesos.

The jump in other expenses -- up 603.3 million pesos from the same quarter a year earlier -- reflected a one-time charge after the sale of its investment in U.S. broadcaster Univision Communications Inc. UVN.N

Analysts think Televisa received less than it expected for the sale. Late last month, Televisa said it had sold its minority interest in Univision for $1.094 billion. Televisa sources declined to elaborate on the charge.

Net profit was also hurt after Televisa, famous for its soap operas that it sells around the world, reported a 244.4 million peso increase in losses at affiliates.

The sharp decline in quarterly profits was also due to 35 million pesos more in income taxes, the company said.

($1=11.044 pesos as of end March)

entry.headline: Microsoft paying up to $180 mln to settle Iowa suit
entry.body:
(Adds details and background)

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp. (MSFT.O) said on Wednesday it agreed to pay up to $180 million to settle a class-action lawsuit, claiming the company has used its monopoly to overcharge citizens in the state of Iowa.

Judge Scott Rosenberg, who presided over the case in Polk County, Iowa, granted preliminary approval to the terms of the settlement. Microsoft had announced in February that it reached a settlement in the case, but did not disclose details at that time.

The court scheduled an Aug. 31 hearing on final approval of the settlement.

Individuals and businesses that purchased Microsoft operating systems and applications between May 18, 1994 and June 30, 2006 will be eligible to file claims.

Microsoft said the settlement dismisses all antitrust and damage claims which had been raised in the case and which could have amounted to $1 billion or more.

The Iowa case and another case in Mississippi are the remaining class-action lawsuits against Microsoft pending in state courts. Microsoft has settled or had dismissed most of the other similar lawsuits in state courts. Two suits failed to win class certification.

entry.headline: Connecticut may sue makers of "Cocaine" drink
entry.body:
BOSTON (Reuters) - Connecticut authorities on Wednesday threatened to sue makers of a canned energy drink called Cocaine, saying it "dangerously glamorizes drug use."

The Las Vegas-based manufacturer, Redux Beverages, will face legal action if it does not immediately stop selling the high-caffeine drink, Connecticut Attorney General Richard Blumenthal said in a statement.

It contains no cocaine but markets itself as "the legal alternative" to the real thing.

Its ingredients include legal stimulants like caffeine, guarana -- a South American seed that is a natural source of caffeine -- and taurine, an amino acid.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has also notified the company that the drink is illegally marketed as a street drug alternative and a dietary supplement.

The drink, which carries a mock health warning saying it can result in "excess excitement, stamina, fun and possible feeling of euphoria," has appeared in stores and the company uses a Web site to market cocktails containing the beverage.

"Naming this product 'Cocaine' is an insult to anyone seeking to deter and discourage illegal drug use," Blumenthal said. "The effect is to verbally trample or obscure the true, hard lessons about cocaine -- for profit."

Officials at Redux Beverages were not immediately available to comment.

Blumenthal said Connecticut is the only state he is aware of taking this step and legal action could entail damages and an injunction against the drink.

The judge presiding over the case in Polk County, Iowa, granted preliminary approval on Wednesday to the terms of the settlement. Microsoft announced it reached a settlement in the case in February, but did not disclose details at the time.

entry.headline: US STOCKS-Dow rises to record, buoyed by JPMorgan and Boeing
entry.body:
(Updates to late afternoon)

By Caroline Valetkevitch

NEW YORK, April 18 (Reuters) - The Dow Jones industrial average set a lifetime high on Wednesday as stronger-than-expected profits from JPMorgan Chase Co. (JPM.N) overshadowed disappointing results from tech bellwethers such as Yahoo and IBM.

The Dow eclipsed its previous intraday record high of 12,795.93 set on Feb. 20, a week before a global sell-off hit equities markets. The average is on track to surpass its previous closing record of 12,786.64, also set on Feb. 20.

A string of big corporate buyouts and data showing steady economic growth, fueled by consumer spending, have helped the 30-stock Dow average bounce back from its 416-point loss on Feb. 27.

Shares of JPMorgan Chase, the No. 3 U.S. bank, and Boeing Co. (BA.N), the world's biggest-selling commercial jetmaker, ranked among the biggest positive influences on the blue-chip Dow average. For details, see [ID:nN18454450].

"One of the things that's been impressive is that earnings reports we've seen so far have been generally positive. I think the big concern going into this earnings season was how financial stocks were going to do, given the subprime problems," said Sam Rahman, portfolio manager at Baring Asset Management Inc. in Boston.

"There are a lot of people out there who are bearish, but the market continues to climb that wall of worry," he said.

The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 44.69 points, or 0.35 percent, at 12,817.73. The Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX was up 2.89 points, or 0.20 percent, at 1,474.37. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was down 1.96 points, or 0.08 percent, at 2,514.99.

JPMorgan's stock gained 4 percent at $52.19 after reaching an all-time high of $52.39.

Boeing's stock climbed 3.7 percent to a record high at $93.83 after news that the U.S. aerospace company was the sole bidder for a $2.5 billion South Korean jet deal. [ID:nN18284048].

But tech stocks fell following disappointing results from Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O) and International Business Machines Corp.(IBM.N), which were released after Tuesday's closing bell.

Yahoo shares slid 11.6 percent to $28.38 on the Nasdaq, while IBM's stock dropped 2.4 percent to $94.82 on the New York Stock Exchange. (Additional reporting by Kristina Cooke)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-General Electric mulls UK power plant sale
entry.body:
(Adds details, comment)

LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) - GE Energy, the energy arm of U.S. conglomerate General Electric (GE.N), is studying the sale of its Baglan Bay gas-fired power plant in Britain, a company spokeswoman said on Wednesday.

"We are now considering plans to sell Baglan Bay," she said, adding that the company has hired corporate financial advisers Lexicon Partners to look into the possible sale.

She would not comment on a report in Wednesday's Daily Telegraph newspaper that GE Energy hoped to raise up to 500 million pounds ($1.01 billion) for the 510-megawatt plant in Port Talbot, South Wales.

She denied the newspaper's report that the plant had already been put up for sale.

The plant -- which has an efficiency rate of 60 percent -- opened in September 2003 but may have served its purpose for GE as the system it was designed to pioneer has now been tested.

"GE owned and operated the Baglan Bay power station as the launch and validation site for our H System advanced turbine and combined cycle technology," the spokeswoman said.

"We have engaged Lexicon Partners as an adviser for the purpose of exploring the possibility of a sale of the facility."

entry.headline: US STOCKS-Tech shares fall on IBM, Yahoo results
entry.body:
(Updates to early morning)

By Kristina Cooke

NEW YORK, April 18 (Reuters) - U.S. technology stocks fell on Wednesday after disappointing results from Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O) and IBM (IBM.N) raised concerns about the outlook for tech spending.

Shares of International Business Machines Corp. dropped more than 2 percent and were the biggest drag on the Dow. But a 4 percent rise in shares of JPMorgan Chase Co. (JPM.N), which posted a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit, buoyed the blue-chip average. For details, see [ID:nN18454450].

Technology shares are often seen as an indicator for the health of the economy.

"Tech, particularly after news from Yahoo, is obviously the big disappointment of the day, and is weighing on the market," said Eric Kuby, chief investment officer at North Star Investment Management Corp. in Chicago.

"But the market is not selling off very sharply, considering how much it has been going up. Financial stocks, which people were worried about, seem to be trading well today."

The Dow Jones industrial average .DJI was up 2.84 points, or 0.02 percent, at 12,775.88. The Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX was down 1.00 points, or 0.07 percent, at 1,470.48. The Nasdaq Composite Index .IXIC was down 9.68 points, or 0.38 percent, at 2,507.27.

The Dow industrials' march toward a record high stalled on Wednesday. The gauge came within striking distance of the Feb. 20 record close of 12,786.64.

Internet company Yahoo reported an 11 percent fall in first-quarter profit, missing Wall Street estimates. [ID:nN1794147]

Jefferies Co. cut its price target on Yahoo to $36 from $38, according to theflyonthewall.com, and Yahoo's shares fell 11.84 percent to $28.29, making it one of the biggest drags on both the SP and the Nasdaq.

Shares of IBM, the world's largest technology services company, fell after it reported net income rose to $1.84 billion, or $1.21 per share, matching Wall Street estimates. [nN17189627]. IBM's stock declined 2 percent to $95.15.

Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock, with Goldman citing IBM's comments about a weaker U.S. spending environment.

Helping to limit the market's losses were financial companies' stocks. The SP index of financial shares .GSPF was up nearly 1 percent.

JPMorgan Chase, the No. 3 U.S. bank, hit an all-time high after the company said quarterly earnings increased, helped by gains in investment banking and private equity. Its shares rose 3.7 percent to $52.05 after reaching a high of $52.39.

Still in the pipeline on Wednesday are earnings from Internet auctioneer eBay Inc. (EBAY.O), which reports after the bell.

entry.headline: JPMorgan nears Canary Wharf move decision -sources
entry.body:
(Adds JPMorgan comment, details)

By Jeffrey Goldfarb and William Kemble-Diaz

LONDON, April 18 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase & Co (JPM.N) expects to decide by mid-May whether to move its London investment banking operations eastwards to Canary Wharf from the City, sources familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

One of the sources, who requested anonymity, said any move was unlikely to happen for another four to five years, and would not affect JP Morgan's treasury and securities services or asset management operations.

It would, however, include its booming investment banking division, potentially dealing a blow to the City's reputation as London's financial heartland. The unit is currently spread among seven City locations now.

The U.S. investment bank -- which was founded in London in 1837 -- is weighing a site at the Riverside South area just off Westferry Circus at Canary Wharf in east London and another at Fore Street in the historic City financial district, the sources said.

It is especially keen to develop several new trading floors of at least 50,000 square feet each.

"We have several attractive scenarios from which to choose and we are looking at them all," a JPMorgan spokesman said. The bank declined to go into detail.

JPMorgan earlier on Wednesday reported a 55 percent rise in quarterly earnings, spurred in part by investment banking.

Although the City -- or "square mile" -- is synonymous with London as a global financial centre, several prominent financial groups already have their UK headquarters at Canary Wharf.

Among them are HSBC (HSBA.L), Barclays (BARC.L), Credit Suisse (CSGN.VX), Lehman Brothers LEH.N, Bank of America (BAC.N) and Morgan Stanley (MS.N).

Merrill Lynch MER.N, Deutsche Bank (DBKGn.DE), UBS (UBSN.VX), ING (ING.AS), Goldman Sachs (GS.N) and ABN AMRO AAH.AS are in the City and its surrounding area.

Songbird Estates SBDb.L, which owns the Riverside site and has planning permission to develop 1.8 million square feet

(167,200 sq. metres) of space on it, declined to comment.

entry.headline: US STOCKS-Wall St seen falling on tech, JP Morgan up
entry.body:
(Adds Motorola, updates prices)

By Kristina Cooke

NEW YORK, April 18 (Reuters) - U.S. stock futures pointed to a lower open on Wall Street on Wednesday, dragged down by investor concerns about technology spending after disappointing results from Yahoo Inc. (YHOO.O) and brokerage downgrades of IBM. (IBM.N)

JPMorgan Chase Co. (JPM.N), the No. 3 U.S. bank, reported a 55 percent rise in quarterly profit, which sent its shares higher and lent brief support to futures. For details, see [ID:nN18454450].

A sharp drop in the dollar could also spread caution in the stock market where the Dow industrials stood just short of a record high after Tuesday's gains.

Analysts fear a weaker dollar could contribute to domestic inflation as prices of imports rise.

"With the market being at high levels, investors are going to take a bit more of a cautious attitude as the earnings season moves into full gear," said Peter Cardillo, chief market economist at Avalon Partners in New York.

"A mixed bag of earnings is weighing down on stocks. The dollar is hitting lows against the pound and other currencies, and that somewhere along the line is also a negative for equities."

SP 500 futures SPc1 were down 3.9 points, below fair value, a mathematical formula that evaluates pricing by taking into account interest rates, dividends and time to expiration on the contract.

Dow Jones industrial average futures DJc1 were down 22 points and Nasdaq 100 NDc1 futures were down 10.5 points.

Internet company Yahoo reported an 11 percent fall in first-quarter profit after the bell on Tuesday, missing Wall Street estimates. [ID:nN1794147] Jefferies Co. cut its price target on Yahoo to $36 from $38, according to theflyonthewall.com. Yahoo's shares fell 2 percent in Europe.

In more negative news for tech, shares of Research In Motion RIMM.O fell 2 percent before the bell after a news report that a system failure had affected users of its Blackberry handheld devices in the Western Hemisphere.

International Business Machines Corp., the world's largest technology services company, reported net income rose to $1.84 billion, or $1.21 per share, matching Wall Street estimates. [nN17189627]. Credit Suisse and Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock, with Goldman citing slower U.S. spending growth.

JPMorgan Chase said on Wednesday quarterly earnings increased, helped by gains in investment banking and private equity. Its shares rose 2.7 percent to $51.51 in electronic trade.

Motorola Inc. MOT.N, the world's second-biggest mobile phone maker, posted a quarterly loss and lower revenue due to weak handset pricing and a limited portfolio of advanced phones. Its shares fell 0.9 percent to $17.78 in electronic trade.

JP Morgan raised its rating on Intel, while Merrill Lynch raised its second-quarter loss estimate for Advanced Micro Devices Inc. (AMD.N), an Intel rival.

Still in the pipeline today are earnings from Internet auctioneer eBay Inc. (EBAY.O), which reports after the bell.

entry.headline: Coca-Cola reports higher first-quarter profit
entry.body:
(Adds revenue, details)

NEW YORK, April 17 (Reuters) - Coca-Cola Co. (KO.N), the world's largest beverage company, on Tuesday reported higher quarterly profit that beat Wall Street estimates as strength in emerging markets overshadowed weakness in North America.

Net income for the first quarter ended March 30 rose 14 percent to $1.26 billion, or 54 cents per share, from $1.11 billion, or 47 cents per share, a year earlier.

Excluding items including a charge from an asset write-off in a Philippines bottler and gains on the sales of an equity interest in a Brazilian bottler, the company earned 56 cents per share.

Analysts on average were expecting 53 cents per share, according to Reuters Estimates.

Coca-Cola, like rival PepsiCo Inc. (PEP.N), has seen a slowdown in sales in mature markets such as North America as increasingly health-conscious consumers opt for bottled water or tea.

Coke's North American sales were flat last year, while sales in Eurasia grew in the double-digits.

Net operating revenue rose 17 percent to $6.10 billion as worldwide unit case volume, a key metric in the beverage industry, grew 6 percent, helped by strength in Latin America, China, Eastern Europe, and South Africa.

Case volume was down 3 percent in North America, up 7 percent in Latin America, and up 11 percent in Europe.

Coke shares have been trading in their highest range since July 2004 in recent weeks. Before Tuesday, the the stock traded at more than 19 times estimated 2007 earnings, making it the second-priciest stock in the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI on a price to earnings basis, though its multiple is only slightly higher than that of rival PepsiCo.

entry.headline: IBM profit up on software and services
entry.body:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - International Business Machines Corp. (IBM.N), the world's largest technology services company, said on Tuesday that quarterly profit rose 8 percent on higher sales of software and computer services.

Net income rose to $1.84 billion, or $1.21 per share, matching Wall Street estimates. A year earlier, it earned $1.71 billion, or $1.08 per share.

Revenue climbed 6.6 percent to $22.03 billion from $20.66 billion a year earlier and topped expectations of $21.9 billion, according to Reuters Estimates.

Following the earnings report in after-hours trading, IBM shares slipped 91 cents to $96.21 after closing up 1 percent.

"The worry going into the quarter was sluggishness (in) server spending, but the fact that IBM pulled off the quarter shows that the diversified portfolio of businesses is working," said Sunil Reddy, senior portfolio manager at Fifth Third Asset Management, which oversees about $21 billion, including IBM shares.

The company stood by its January forecast of full-year earnings-per-share growth of 10 percent to 12 percent, adding that growth would likely be around 11 percent.

IBM Chief Financial Officer Mark Loughridge told analysts on a conference call that weakness in the United States was more than offset by strong sales in Asia and in Europe, especially in Germany.

IBM paid nearly $5 billion for 13 acquisitions to boost sales of software and services last year, part of a strategy to improve profitability by selling more software-based services.

IBM said revenue at its two services businesses, which accounted for more than one-half of total sales in 2006, rose 8 percent in the quarter. Services signings, a key indicator of future revenue, slipped to $11.1 billion from $11.4 billion.

Revenue at one services unit, Global Business Services, increased 8.7 percent to $4.2 billion. It was the eighth consecutive quarter of year-over-year pretax profit growth for the business, reflecting IBM's push to sell more-profitable software-based services.

Revenue at the other services unit, Global Technology Services, rose 7 percent to $8.3 billion. The first unit includes consulting and managing of customers' business software, while the other is involved in outsourcing and computer maintenance.

First-quarter services deals included a $775 million contract to manage information technology for more than 600 Circuit City CC.N stores.

IBM, of Armonk, New York, also signed a $700 million extension of a contract with Germany's Sparkassen Informatik GmbH, which handles information technology for savings banks.

Software revenue rose 8.8 percent to $4.25 billion in the first quarter, helped by strong sales of IBM's middleware software for running corporate data networks. Middleware is a layer of software that connects applications or components.

Sales of hardware, including microprocessors and servers and storage gear for businesses, rose 2.3 percent to $4.52 billion.

The stock closed up 94 cents at $97.12 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Shares are down 2.3 percent this year amid investor concern over revenue and profit growth for 2007. The stock trades at about 14 times estimated 2007 earnings per share, compared with an average multiple of about 15 for companies on the Standard Poor's 500 Index .SPX, including competitor Hewlett-Packard Co. (HPQ.N)

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-RESEARCH ALERT-JP Morgan ups Intel rating, '07 EPS view
entry.body:
(Recasts, adds details)

April 18 (Reuters) - J.P. Morgan Securities upgraded Intel Corp. (INTC.O) to "overweight," saying its share gains, stable pricing and lower costs should drive margin expansion during second half of 2007.

The brokerage raised its 2007 earnings estimates for the chip maker to $1.03 a share from $1.00, but lowered its revenue estimates to $36.9 billion from $37.1 billion.

J.P. Morgan said it had been positive on Intel's improved products and restructuring efforts, but were concerned on risk to margins due to excess processor capacity and aggressive pricing.

The brokerage said that Intel's superior products are taking their toll on rival AMD (AMD.N), which led to a 3 percent gain in market share during first-quarter of 2007. J.P. Morgan added that Intel should gain share again during second-quarter.

"We expect Intel gross margins to bottom in second-quarter of 2007 and recover in the second half of 2007 due to lower start up costs, higher revenues and improved unit costs," J.P. Morgan said in a brokerage note.

J.P. Morgan said while Intel's inventory is still "too high", it sees inventories decreasing in the second half of the year due to improved unit shipments and a seasonal increase in PC demand. (Reporting by Debojyoti Ghosh in Bangalore)

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-Chevron optimistic about Venezuelan takeover
entry.body:
(Recasts paragraph 2, adds quotes paragraphs 3-4)

By Tom Brown

MIAMI, April 19 (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) is optimistic about the future of foreign oil companies in Venezuela's vast Orinoco reserve after the government's planned takeover of multibillion-dollar projects there, a Chevron executive said on Thursday.

Peter Sommer, Chevron's commercial manager for Latin American exploration and production, said the move by the leftist government of President Hugo Chavez stopped short of an outright nationalization of one of the world's largest oil reserves.

"In the old days nationalization was -- they kick out the oil companies and their nationals took over 100 percent of the operations," he said.

"This is a little bit different, so I guess the word is recapitalization," he said at a Latin American conference sponsored by the University of Miami's Center for Hemispheric Policy.

Sommer said negotiations are still under way over the government's plan to take a majority stake in Orinoco projects valued at more than $30 billion and funded by Chevron, Exxon Mobil (XOM.N), Conoco Phillips (COP.N), Norway's Statoil (STL.OL), Britain's BP Plc (BP.L) and France's Total (TOTF.PA).

But some degree of confidence about the talks was fueled by negotiations between the Chavez government and foreign oil majors last year, when Sommer said the foreign operators "were fairly well treated" in operating service agreements.

"We're optimistic that on these conversions of the heavy oil projects there's an opportunity for the companies to come out OK," he said, referring to the Orinoco contract talks.

High prices have allowed foreign operators to generate big profits from Venezuelan oil, despite their sometimes harsh treatment by Chavez.

On May 1, Venezuela's state oil company takes over the operation of four heavy crude upgrader projects in the Orinoco and has decreed that the new ownership structure for the joint ventures should be finalized by June 26.

The projects can produce 600,000 barrels of oil per day.

Underpinning his upbeat assessment, Sommer said Venezuela, a member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, needs foreign cooperation.

"They recognize they need the foreign oil companies. They need our technology, and they need our capital," he said.

"We need to go where the reserves are, sometimes in countries that have difficult local policies to deal with," Sommer said, speaking of the oil industry in general.

"It's our job to be above that and just be a good international investor and partner."

entry.headline: Mexico's Televisa has eyes on Satmex satellite firm
entry.body:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Televisa said it is interested in buying Satmex, a move that could return it to the satellite business, cut transmission costs and strengthen the Mexican broadcaster's footprint from Canada to Argentina.

Satmex is Mexico's main satellite operator but the company was in financial trouble until it refinanced its bulky debt last year.

Televisa said it had not decided yet if it will bid for the firm.

"We are just analyzing it. We are in the process of due diligence. We are learning about that business, about the synergies that it would have with other (Televisa) business segments," executive vice president Alfonso De Angoitia told an analysts' conference call on Thursday.

Due diligence is an investigation of a potential investment and helps companies gather key information regarding a sale.

"However, we have not made any decision yet on whether we are going forward or not," De Angoitia added.

Satmex said last month that it expected to go on auction during the first half of May. European and U.S. satellite operators are also looking at the company.

Televisa uses satellite signals to transmit its programming to partners all across the American continent. The potential acquisition could help cut those transmission costs and get additional revenue from renting Satmex transponders to other broadcasters.

In 1998, Televisa pulled out from a venture it had with PanAmSat by selling its stake in the satellite operator to Hughes Electronics Corp.

Televisa shares ended up 0.42 percent at 66.40 pesos while its New York Big Board traded shares edged up 0.4 percent to close at $30.12.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-MOVES-Fidelity, JPMorgan, Blackstone
entry.body:
(Adds Fidelity, JPMorgan, Blackstone)

PHILADELPHIA/BANGALORE, April 19 (Reuters) - The following financial service industry appointments were announced on Thursday. To inform us of other job changes, please e-mail moves@reuters.com

FIDELITY INVESTMENTS

Fidelity, the world's biggest mutual fund company, said its vice chairman and chief operating officer Robert Reynolds will retire.

Ellyn McColgan, president of Fidelity Brokerage Co., was promoted to oversee distribution and operations in a role shared with Abigail Johnson, daughter of Fidelity Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Edward Johnson.

Fidelity, which manages $1.4 trillion in assets, also said John Remondi has been named interim chief administrative officer.

JPMORGAN CHASE CO. (JPM.N)

Joe Jiampietro will join JPMorgan as a managing director in the financial institutions and governments group as part of its banks coverage team, according to an internal JPMorgan memo that was obtained by Reuters.

Jiampietro joins JPMorgan from UBS AG (UBSN.VX), where he focused on banks and diversified financial services, the memo said. He will join JPMorgan in July.

Jiampietro is the second financial institutions banker that JPMorgan has hired from UBS in recent weeks. Last month, JPMorgan said it hired Eric Warmstein from UBS.

THE BLACKSTONE GROUP

Blackstone said Susan Balloch joined its private equity group as an executive director, focusing on management and administrative functions. Balloch was formerly with Welsh, Carson, Anderson Stowe in their investor relations group.

CREDIT SUISSE (CSGN.VX)

The investment bank has poached Martin Bastian from Goldman Sachs to oversee the bank's coverage of the European chemicals sector, according to an internal memo circulated on Thursday and seen by Reuters. Bastian is expected to join on May 1 and be based in London, according to the memo. [nL1999812]

WACHOVIA CORP. WB.N

The U.S. bank named Ranjana Clark, former head of its treasury services division, to head a new marketing division encompassing corporate marketing, e-commerce, market research, customer service and innovation.

FC ASSET MANAGEMENT FCAM.L

The fund manager named Erik Rubingh as head of quantitative equity strategies, based in London. He joins from ABP Investments.

entry.headline: Chevron "optimistic" about Venezuelan takeover
entry.body:
MIAMI (Reuters) - Chevron Corp. (CVX.N) is "optimistic" about the future of foreign oil companies in Venezuela's vast Orinoco reserve following the government's planned takeover of their multibillion-dollar projects there, a company official said on Thursday.

"We're optimistic that on these conversions of the heavy oil projects there's an opportunity for the companies to come out OK," said Peter Sommer, Chevron's commercial manager for Latin American exploration and production.

Sommer, who spoke at a Latin American conference sponsored by the University of Miami's Center for Hemispheric Policy, said negotiations over the nationalizations affecting investments by Chevron, Exxon Mobil (XOM.N), Conoco Phillips (COP.N), Norway's Statoil (STL.OL), Britain's BP Plc (BP.L) and Total (TOTF.PA) of France were still under way.

"We are just analyzing it. We are in the process of due diligence. We are learning about that business, about the synergies that it would have with other (Televisa ) business segments," Executive Vice President Alfonso De Angoitia told an analysts' conference call.

"However, we have not made any decision yet on whether we are going forward or not," he added.

entry.headline: Mexico's Televisa posts surprise 1st-qtr profit plunge
entry.body:
(Adds details, analyst quote, byline)

By Cyntia Barrera Diaz

MEXICO CITY, April 18 (Reuters) - Mexican broadcaster Televisa posted a surprise 46 percent plunge in first-quarter earnings, hurt by a one-time charge from the sale of its stake in U.S. partner Univision, losses in affiliates and higher taxes.

Grupo Televisa (TV.N) (TLVACPO.MX) said on Wednesday it earned 734 million pesos ($66 million), compared with 1.348 billion pesos in the first quarter of 2006. Results came in way below analysts' consensus estimate of 1.450 billion pesos.

The jump in other expenses -- up 603.3 million pesos from the same quarter a year earlier -- reflected a one-time charge after the sale of its investment in U.S. broadcaster Univision Communications Inc. UVN.N.

Analysts think Televisa received less than it expected for the sale. Late last month, Televisa said it had sold its minority interest in Univision for $1.094 billion.

"I think that the difference between market value and the price they had projected (for the Univision stake) is what caused this virtual loss," said analyst Raul Ochoa with HSBC.

Net profit was also hurt after Televisa, famous for its soap operas that it sells around the world, reported a 244.4 million peso increase in losses at affiliates, particularly at its Spanish venture La Sexta, in which it holds a 40 percent interest.

Quarterly profits also fell sharply because income taxes increased by 35 million pesos, the company said.

Quarterly revenue rose 5.9 percent to 8.232 billion pesos

($745 million), above analysts' expectations, driven by its satellite and cable television businesses.

Televisa's core broadcasting sales fell 3.8 percent in the quarter.

"This decrease reflects primarily the absence of political advertising related to the presidential elections in Mexico sold during the first quarter of 2006," the company said.

Mexican broadcasters benefited from political and soccer World Cup advertising during the first half of last year.

Satellite unit SKY reported a 11 percent rise in first-quarter revenue while sales at cable television unit Cablevision grew by 28 percent in the period.

Other business segments with strong revenue growth in the quarter were programming exports, driven by royalties from Univision, and magazine publishing.

Televisa shares fell 0.88 percent to close at 66.12 pesos on Wednesday while its New York-traded shares dropped 1.19 percent to $30.

($1=11.044 pesos as of end March)

(Additional reporting by Armando Tovar)

entry.headline: Goldman to buy 18 pct stake in Japan's Usen
entry.body:
TOKYO, April 19 (Reuters) - Goldman Sachs Group Inc. (GS.N) said on Thursday that a unit would pay 25 billion yen ($210 million) for an 18 percent stake in Japanese cable broadcaster Usen Corp. 4842.OJ, making it the second-biggest shareholder.

Usen, which also offers broadband Internet service and operates karaoke rooms, said it would issue about 24.5 million new shares at 1,020 yen apiece, or a 2.7 percent discount to Thursday's closing price. It plans to use the proceeds to repay debt.

The Goldman unit will become the No. 2 shareholder behind Usen President Yasuhide Uno, which last year bought 30 billion yen worth of stock in the company. Uno's stake will fall to 44.5 percent after Goldman buys the latest batch of new shares.

entry.headline: Microsoft aims to add 1 bln more users by 2015
entry.body:
SEATTLE (Reuters) - Microsoft Corp., trying to meet its goal of doubling the number of computer users to 2 billion by 2015, promised to cut its software prices to governments in developing countries that provide free computers to school children.

Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates announced the program at a news conference in Beijing on Thursday.

Redmond, Washington-based Microsoft said it plans to offer a software package called Microsoft Student Innovation Suite for $3 to governments purchasing and giving Windows-based computer to primary and secondary students.

The software bundle, which will be available in the second half of 2007, includes Windows XP Starter Edition, Microsoft Office Home and Student 2007, Windows Live Mail desktop and other programs.

"This is not a philanthropic effort, this is a business," Orlando Ayala, senior vice president at Microsoft's emerging segments market development group in an interview before the official announcement.

In many emerging markets, Microsoft has seen its software pirated and sold at a fraction of the price of a genuine product. Microsoft said the technology industry must also adapt business models to developing nations.

The company is working with retailers and computer makers in Brazil to test a pay-as-you-go system, because that model has been successful with mobile phones in the country.

entry.headline: JPMorgan earnings rise, boosted by investment bank
entry.body:
(Adds background and details, share reaction)

NEW YORK, April 18 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM.N) on Wednesday reported a 55 percent increase in quarterly earnings, helped by gains in investment banking and private equity, and bolstered its dividend and stock buyback plan.

Net income rose to $4.8 billion, or $1.34 a share from $3.1 billion, or 86 cents, a year ago.

Results were boosted by a one-time gain of $391 million, or 11 cents a share from the adoption of a new accounting rule.

Analysts, on average, had forecast earnings of $1.02 before extraordinary items, according to Reuters Estimates.

JPMorgan shares were up 2.9 percent in pre-market electronic trading after the results.

The No. 3 U.S. bank also said it was raising its quarterly dividend by 12 percent to 38 cents a share and authorized a new $10 billion stock buyback program.

The repurchase plan replaces a prior, $8 billion one which had $850 million remaining to be bought. JPMorgan shares are up 3.9 percent so far this year, outperforming the KBW Banks index .BKX, which was down 1.9 percent for the same period.

The No. 3 U.S. bank has been focused on growth, changing course from its previous focus on cost savings from a series of previous acquisitions and mergers.

Executives have said they plan to invest $1 billion in investment banking in 2007 -- about one third greater than in 2006 -- to expand in markets including energy trading in Asia. Investment banking was one of the bank's strongest areas in the quarter, posting an 81 percent gain in profit to $1.54 billion, helped by strong revenue from fees.

Retail banking profit fell 2 percent to $859 million as its provision for credit losses more than tripled from a year ago to $292 million due to higher losses in its subprime mortgage portfolio and on home equity loans.

Gains on private equity investments helped JPMorgan's corporate bank swing to a $631 million profit from a $366 million loss in the year-ago period.

entry.headline: UPDATE 2-Pfizer puts hold on HDL drugs like torcetrapib
entry.body:
(Adds details on Lipitor in paragraphs 7-9)

NEW YORK, April 20 (Reuters) - Pfizer Inc. said on Friday it was placing a hold on development of any drugs in the same class as torcetrapib, its experimental product that dramatically raised "good" HDL cholesterol but was scrapped after being linked to deaths in a large trial.

Pfizer (PFE.N) research chief John LaMattina told analysts on a conference call that torcetrapib's failure to cut levels of plaque in coronary arteries, even as it sharply raised HDL, had shaken confidence in the so-called CETP-inhibitor class of drugs.

"That has given us and a lot of other people pause," said LaMattina, whose company last year had highlighted the potential of its other CETP inhibitors in earlier stages of testing. But that was before Pfizer scrapped torcetrapib, whose late-stage trials were the most costly in history, last December.

"We have not ended development of the drugs; we've put them on hold," a Pfizer spokesman said, as the company continues to assess potential of the medicines.

He said Pfizer had halted an early-stage trial of one CETP inhibitor, in the wake of torcetrapib's failure, but had already completed an early-stage trial of another drug in the class.

Similar drugs are being developed by Merck & Co. (MRK.N) and by a partnership of Roche Holding AG (ROG.VX) and Japan Tobacco Inc. (2914.T)

During the conference call, Pfizer executives said favorable rebate trends that bolstered first-quarter sales of cholesterol fighter Lipitor will turn "slightly negative" during the remainder of 2007, crimping performance of the company's biggest product.

Global Lipitor sales rose 8 percent to $3.36 billion in the quarter, although the number of prescriptions fell in the important United States market.

The product's first-quarter sales growth was due to price hikes and favorable rebate trends in the period, company officials said.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Pfizer earnings fall, hurt by charges, generics
entry.body:
(Adds details)

NEW YORK, April 20 (Reuters) - Pfizer Inc. (PFE.N) said on Friday quarterly earnings fell on special charges, anemic sales of inhaled diabetes drug Exubera and plunging demand for drugs facing generic competition, sending shares down 2.5 percent.

The world's largest drugmaker said its 2007 earnings will be below Wall Street expectations due to the unexpectedly swift introduction of cheaper generic forms of its hypertension treatment Norvasc.

Pfizer said 2008 revenue will be little changed from 2007, which itself was expected to be flat with last year.

Pfizer also warned that sales of its biggest product, cholesterol fighter Lipitor could have "modest growth to modest decline" this year because more U.S. patients than expected switched to cheaper generic forms of Merck & Co's (MRK.N) rival Zocor.

Pfizer earned $3.39 billion, or 48 cents per share, in the first quarter, compared with $4.11 billion, or 56 cents per share, in the year-ago period.

Excluding special items, New York-based Pfizer earned 68 cents per share. Analysts on average expected 57 cents per share, according to Reuters Estimates.

Revenue rose 6 percent to $12.47 billion, topping the Reuters Estimate of $11.77 billion, helped by surging sales of its drug Lyrica used to treat neuropathic pain.

Company sales growth has also stalled due to generic competition for other former big-sellers, including antibiotic Zithromax and anti-depressant Zoloft.

Pfizer in January said revenue in 2007 should be flat, but that earnings would grow about 6 percent to 9 percent thanks in part to ongoing cost-cutting efforts, including an ongoing effort to cut 10,000 jobs by 2008.

entry.headline: UPDATE 1-Astra follows Pfizer with new UK drug sales scheme
entry.body:
(Adds details and background)

LONDON, April 20 (Reuters) - AstraZeneca Plc (AZN.L) followed Pfizer Inc. (PFE.N) on Friday by unveiling an exclusive distribution system for its medicines in Britain, in a move that is likely to anger third-party distributors.

The Anglo-Swedish group said it had appointed AAH Pharmaceuticals and UniChem, the wholesaling division of Alliance Boots Plc AB.L, as its agency partners to deliver medicines directly to pharmacies, doctors and hospitals.

The new supply system, which AstraZeneca plans to implement in late summer, replaces the traditional one of supplying products indirectly through multiple wholesalers.

AstraZeneca said it had made the change to "simplify and modernise" supply arrangements.

But the move will add to controversy about a trend which Pfizer started last month when it began selling its products through a single wholesaler. The U.S. giant also chose UniChem.

Britain's consumer affairs watchdog, the Office of Fair Trading, said two weeks ago it would investigate the market for distributing medicines in the wake of the Pfizer move, although this probe will not stop the new scheme from continuing.

Independent wholesalers argue that exclusive distribution deals stifle competition and could undermine Britain's flexible round-the-clock drug-ordering and delivery service.

entry.headline: NEWSMAKER-Helen Walton, influential widow of Wal-Mart founder
entry.body:
CHICAGO, April 20 (Reuters) - Helen Walton, the matriarch of one of the richest families in U.S. business history who died on Thursday, made a key decision 62 years ago that likely changed the course of retailing in the United States.

In 1945, Mrs. Walton refused to live in a town larger than 10,000, which meant her husband, Sam, gave up his dream of running a department store in St. Louis and instead invested in a Ben Franklin variety store in tiny Newport, Arkansas.

From that little store eventually grew the Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT.N) empire that is now the world's biggest retailer.

Mrs. Walton, widow of legendary Wal-Mart's founder "Mr. Sam," died of natural causes after having been in poor health recently. She was 87.

The woman her husband called "pretty and smart and educated, ambitious and opinionated and strong-willed," was also responsible for giving women a greater role in running Wal-Mart.

She pressed her husband to include women on the board of directors -- which he did in 1986, bringing on Arkansas lawyer and first lady of the state, Hillary Clinton.

Mrs. Walton didn't win every battle, though. She also complained about Sam forcing Wal-Mart managers to work on Saturdays, a policy -- still commonplace at Wal-Mart -- she said damaged families because it kept parents away from their children.

Helen Walton was born on Dec. 3, 1919, and graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a degree in finance.

She met her future husband at a bowling alley in her hometown of Claremore, Oklahoma, and they were married on Valentine's Day in 1943.

They had four children; Rob, John, Jim and Alice; eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Rob Walton now serves as Wal-Mart's chairman. John Walton died in a plane crash in 2005.

In 1950, five years after opening the Ben Franklin store, Sam opened Walton's 510 in Bentonville, Arkansas, where Wal-Mart is still based. Sam opened his first Wal-Mart discount store in Rogers, Arkansas, not far from Bentonville, in 1962.

Sam's strategy was to bring low prices to underserved rural communities, and many analysts contend that his plan might not have worked so well had he targeted larger cities from the start.

Wal-Mart now faces fierce opposition as it tries to expand into major urban areas. Critics allege that Wal-Mart forces local retailers out of business, drives down employee wages, increases traffic, and hurts the environment.

FAMILY FORTUNE

Mrs. Walton ranked 11th on the 2006 Forbes list of the richest Americans.

Other Walton family members hold four of the top 10 spots. The family's combined fortune is above that of the richest person, Bill Gates. The Walton family controls around 40 percent of Wal-Mart's stock.

After Sam's death in 1992, Helen Walton served as a vital link to her husband's legacy at a company that still turns to the words of its founder for wisdom. Company executives routinely quote from Sam's autobiography, and use clips of his speeches to motivate employees.

U.S. Sen. Clinton, who left the Wal-Mart board in 1992 as Bill Clinton campaigned for president, said it was Helen and daughter Alice who convinced Sam that it was time to break up the boardroom boys' club and invite women to join the ranks of directors.

Sam phoned Clinton and said, "They tell me I have to have a woman on the board. Do you want to be her?" Clinton recalled in a January 2004 speech to the National Retail Federation.

Sam had a chance to buy a Federated department store in St. Louis in 1945, but Helen "laid down the law," as Sam put it in his 1992 autobiography.

"Sam, we've been married two years and we've moved 16 times. Now, I'll go with you any place you want so long as you don't ask me to live in a big city. Ten thousand people is enough for me," she said.

Helen Walton always drew standing ovations from the 18,000-strong crowds when she arrived at Wal-Mart annual meetings. Her health, however, did not permit her to attend in recent years.

entry.headline: Mexico's Televisa has eyes on Satmex satellite firm
entry.body:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Televisa said it is interested in buying Satmex, a move that could return it to the satellite business, cut transmission costs and strengthen the Mexican broadcaster's footprint from Canada to Argentina.

Satmex is Mexico's main satellite operator but the company was in financial trouble until it refinanced its bulky debt last year.

Televisa said it had not decided yet if it will bid for the firm.

"We are just analyzing it. We are in the process of due diligence. We are learning about that business, about the synergies that it would have with other (Televisa) business segments," executive vice president Alfonso De Angoitia told an analysts' conference call on Thursday.

Due diligence is an investigation of a potential investment and helps companies gather key information regarding a sale.

"However, we have not made any decision yet on whether we are going forward or not," De Angoitia added.

Satmex said last month that it expected to go on auction during the first half of May. European and U.S. satellite operators are also looking at the company.

Televisa uses satellite signals to transmit its programming to partners all across the American continent. The potential acquisition could help cut those transmission costs and get additional revenue from renting Satmex transponders to other broadcasters.

In 1998, Televisa pulled out from a venture it had with PanAmSat by selling its stake in the satellite operator to Hughes Electronics Corp.

Televisa shares ended up 0.42 percent at 66.40 pesos while its New York Big Board traded shares edged up 0.4 percent to close at $30.12.
